اختيار (السفارة أو القنصلية المعنية) حسب التوزيع الجغرافي ( رابط تقديم خدمات المواطنين حسب مكان الاقامة ).

على الصورة الشخصية للمستفيد ان تكون واضحة وحديثة بخلفية بيضاء، وبحجم لا يزيد عن 5 ميجابايت.

إرفاق صورة جواز السفر الاصلي  بصيغة jpeg (على ان يرسل الأصل لاحقا حين استلام الجواز الجديد أو حين طلب البعثة ذلك).
إرفاق صورة من خطاب التعريف (خطاب تعريف من مقر العمل اذا كان المواطن موظفاً أو من الملحقية الثقافية اذا كان طالباً مبتعثاً أو من الجامعة اذا كان على حسابه الخاص أو من المستشفى اذا كان المواطن متواجد لغرض العلاج ...).

إرفاق صورة من إثبات الإقامة أو الدراسة.

إرفاق صورة من بطاقة الأحوال المدنية (أو شرح سبب عدم توفرها كتابياً) وإرفاق ذلك في قسم الملحقات الإضافية

.يمكن للمستفيد الطلب من البعثة اعادة الجواز الأصلي واصول المستندات بعد مقارنتها بالأصل ان كانت هناك حاجة، على ان يعاد الجواز الأصلي مرة اخرى للبعثة (لتخريمه وختمه بختم لاغي) عند استلام الجواز الجديد.

إن عدم إرفاق المرفقات الضرورية يعرض طلبك للتأخير أو عدم القبول.على الوثائق المرفقة اللازمة أن لا يزيد حجم الملف الواحد عن 2 ميجابايت وأن تكون بصيغة JPG, JPEG, PNG, TIF, BMP, PDF
.قد يتطلب الأمر حضور صاحب العلاقة شخصياً أو الولي الشرعي.

يلزم حضور ولي الأمر وتوقيعه على استمارة طلب اصدار جواز سفر  أو إرفاق إقرار موافقة خطية مصدقة من قبل جهة حكومية سعودية أو توكيل شرعي من قبل ولي الأمر، وفي حالة المتوفى ولي أمرهم يتم إرفاق صك شرعي يثبت حق الولاية أو الوصاية أو القوامة الشرعية عليهم

إرفاق صورة من موافقة ولي الأمر في حال وجود مرافقين.

قد يتم منحك تذكرة مرور إذا مر أكثر من عام على تاريخ انتهاء جواز السفر.

Hi Justin,

Although we’ve never spoken, I really enjoy reading your twitter feed and I know that you run code & supply in Pittsburgh and other meetups. I just started (2 days ago) an open Slack community for Pittsburgh developers. The purpose is to have a lively discussion about anything development and enable developers to connect to each other easier. I wanted to personally invite you to join. I have a website running on Github pages at: https://pghdevs.github.io/ to promote the channel. 

A little bit about myself: my name is Sam Alghanmi. I graduated from Pitt in 2014. I was doing a Master's in Health Information Systems. I got married here and moved to Denver on October of 2014 till February of this year. I worked as a front-end JavaScript developer, then moved to Full Stack with Nodejs and Express. I just moved back to Pittsburgh. I love the city and I would love to join the community and contribute to it in anyway I can. Here is my Linkedin profile for more information about me: https://www.linkedin.com/in/osama-alghanmi-0957bb28.

You stand out as a leader in the community and your advice and experience would be invaluable. I would love to meet and talk about the channel and if you are interested in joining me to run the channel, it would be an honor. My schedule is pretty open, I am available 

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Best,

Sam

attachment.content:
Osama Alghanmi, a name and a history

2003:

Late at night, Sitting in my room thinking to myself: what's this feeling? why am I feeling like this? I shouldn't have watched it. It's ruined my faith. I am never going to be the same again.

It was a Thursday night in our house in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. My cousin came over, as he always did. We used to have an every other week stay over at our houses. We have falafel wraps usually for dinner, from this amazing restaurant called abu adnan. Abu in arabic means the father of, and is a very popular nickname in many of the arab's cultures. So, my dad came home with a CD. I can't believe I just wrote CD, because at that time they were brand new. Anyways, my dad played the CD and from that time till now, I don't know what was in it, but something popped in my head. I am a Muslim Sunni and the CD was showing the Shia sect's celebration of one of the month were the most observant beat themselves up. I mean, they use many objects to inflict wounds to mourn the death of one of the grandsons of Prophet Muhammad who died because he was let down and not protected which lead to his death. Not to go to much into history, but that's not what made something pop in my head. It was the idea that these people say they are Muslim and they have scholars much like we do. Still they understood the religion in a different way. I remember that night was one of the hardest. Because I started having "satanic thoughts" and "doubts" that usually come from hypocrites. In my culture, hypocrites or people of diseased hearts is people who question or doubt their faith. In my culture, you are supposed to be grateful that you are born into the religion of Islam. You shouldn't question that, otherwise you are a hypocrite, or if you are really lucky, a person with a diseased heart. I was 13 at that time, but from that age till I was 24, I felt really bad about myself. I thought that I am a hypocrite and that I was destined to be a hypocrite till I die and meet my place in hell reserved for people who doubt the religion and feel like they should question what's in it. I remember religion classes and how hard it was for me to not question what's in our books. I remember bits and pieces of my classes and how it made my doubt increase. Our religion teacher in of the classes said this: " We sunnis are really blessed to have the right way. how many are we? 100 million maybe? well, that's enough because everyone else is at risk of going to hell" I couldn't forget that because that really didn't make sense to me. Why am I lucky? does god really choose people to be the saved ones. At that time, I was discouraged to talk to anyone about it. Because you are going to be looked at differently. My parents are very nice and open, but I still had that fear that this side of me is demonic and I should pray to restore my faith. It never came back.

2011:

Let me fast forward almost 10 years after, I met a saudi girl through the traditional way there. In Saudi Arabia, you meet someone and you talk to them on the phone or online till you are ready to propose. After that, you propose and can be with the other person, but it's usually chaperoned. She was the first girl I met and I thought that I am in love. At that time, I started a small company with two of my friends and we were doing IT consulting. We got our biggest project. The project was huge and we were under a lot of stress. I forgot all about my faith and just ignored it all these years. I thought eventually it will go away. It never went away. I was close to getting married (explain the saudi process of marriage). I went through my engagement and on the first day alone with my fiance at the time I was happy, but something weird happened. I started getting these feelings that I can't be physical with another woman. I freaked out. I remember waking up my parents in the middle of the night. I haven't done that since I was 5. My dad got up and as always he smiled. A smile to reassure me. It wasn't just a smile, it was accompanied with a laugh. I still don't know why my dad does that everytime we are in a tough situation. I was telling my parents that I got into an accident and hit my nick and I am feeling a weird sensation in my body. Obviously it was a lie, but what else could I have said? I don't feel sexual with my fiance! We went to the emergency room and they said I am fine and I should take some pain killers. We went back home and my mom was making breakfast because it was almost morning prayer time. From that day and for almost 4 months I went into a crazy period of my life. I started having weird thoughts that I am not myself. I started looking for patterns and trying to figure out what's wrong with me. It's hard for me to write this part, because most of my memory isn't there. I was under many pills and mostly sedated. I will try to explain the progression of my weird thoughts. It all started with paranoia. I was afraid that I can't finish my company's project. Then, I was working with a group of women to build an app for a non-profit. I started feeling guilty that I might have charged too much for the project which lead to me feeling this way. It's god's punishment to me for stealing money! I then proceeded to think that I am receiving signs that I am a hypocrite. It was very intense to the point where I started staying in my bed and just freaking out. I have the personality that freaks out easily. I wasn't really ready for all the responsibilities. I was just weak and didn't experience what it's like to be responsible. I also buried all that guilt of me doubting my faith and it all came out in my period of freakouts. I even went through a phase where I thought I was possessed, yes, possessed by demons. Regardless of all of that, I couldn't maintain my engagement and my fiance couldn't take my craziness and asked for a divorce. I had no feelings at that time, so it didn't seem to be significant next to me being possessed and going to hell. It was that intense! My parents thought I should continue my application and go to the US to finish my studies. That way, I can change the environment. I then went to the US, went online, met a girl, kissed a girl, remembered my ex-fiance and apologized and broke up with her. Talked to another girl online who couldn't talk, couldn't take it and broke up with her. Finally, I just took a time off from all of that. I kept praying and going to the mosque. I also kept praying that I find the right person and the right path. I thought again, if I could go back to my faith, i will be ok. There's no way, no way that my religion could be wrong. I am on the right path. I should ignore my doubts and live my life till death arrives and then explain everything to god. "God I just doubted you. I am sorry. I still prayed just in case I meet you". I started going out and talking to many people as I like to do. I met many interesting people, but felt sorry for them, because they don't know the "true religion" and I prayed they find it someday because I cared about people. That was the reason I doubted religion in the first place. I think all people are equal. I mean equal regardless of the religion they are born into. I don't care about any other explanation. I am not saved because I am from Islam. If there's any way that I could be saved, it's through me being nice to people and not discriminate. 

The woman of my dreams?

My friend wouldn't shut up about this girl that he saw in a networking event for a non-profit called global Pittsburgh. I knew before that, and we had been friends for 3-4 months. I joined him to attend the global Pittsburgh event for the first time. I saw her across the bar and she was just beautiful. My friend was interested in her and wanted to ask for her number. She on the other hand wasn't interested. I didn't want to talk to her because I thought (I have little experience with this) that it would be disrespectful to him. Eventually he told me: "she doesn't seem like she's interested. I am heading out". So I sat down and started talking to her. Her first subject was human trafficking in the US. She instantly caught my attention. I still had thoughts that she has to be converted in order for me to marry her. After all, how can I be with someone if I knew they are going to hell. I felt really bad about it. I had the best times of my life with Rebecca. She was just an amazing person to be around. Intelligent, sophisticated, yet simple and informal. I can't really describe her. I still wasn't ready for the responsibility. I still didn't feel like I could face all my fears. I told her that my parents are looking for a girl for me and that I have to leave to my country to see her. She was upset, but I knew that a Muslim girl who's going to raise my kids the way my culture wanted, is the way to heaven and eternal happiness. We eventually broke up and I was miserable. For the next 3 months all I could think about is her. I was at my friend's house one day and I went outside in an instant and cancelled the pre-engagement process. I emailed becky and she was upset that I am bringing all the pain back to her. She said: "you are delusional, this can never work" I didn't know it would at the time, but I knew that the secret to my happiness is her. I never felt happy with anyone else. She was what I was looking for. I am writing this now and I am thinking how much I love her. I love you Rebecca. She agreed eventually to talk. We talked and it took her a while before she accepted me back. I had my birthday later and she revealed something shocking to me that put our relationship to test. We went through it, but I had and still have jealousy of her past. She told me many times that she was with other people but never cared for them. All I could think of is being with someone else and how impure that's. She should ask for forgiveness for all that to go away! It took me a while before I realized that we live in a culture and it defines who we are. I lied to her about me contacting her because I was abused. I mean I was, but I wanted to talk to her because I missed her deeply. I just didn't find a way to tell her that. I am sorry Rebecca. I am sorry to all the people I put in pain. I was a dishonest person to myself which lead me to be dishonest with others. I am not a believer. This is me being honest. I believe that human beings deserve to live freely and have whatever faith and still get treated equally. I am never going to accept looking at a persona s a beliver who's good and I should look for ways to execuse his flaws because he's my "brother or sister" and I should look at a non-believer as a person who denied the truth and should prosecuted for it. I am agnostic. I don't know. There's no proof. I want to see the proof. I have never met Muhammad. I don't know him. How can I love him. How can I believe that he had miracles. How do I know he's different from other people. Why is the Quran in Arabic and is supposed to be for everyone. How?? How can we treat people equally if we are expected to occupy their land and get their woman and make them pay taxes. We are no different than any other nation if we think that way. These are some of the doubts I have. I still feel guilty , why? why can't I accept that the chances of me going to hell is equal to the chance of my going into a soup bowl after I die? It's the guilt. The guilt embedded into every believer, not just Muslim, but everyone. If Muhammad was really a mercy for the world. Why was he send as a proof to the non-believers so that they won't have an excuse in front of god? why? I believe in god and I think that he's merciful or she I dunno. That's the point. I am not going to calim or argue that I am any better than any person, believer or not, but I know that I am looking for the truth and till I find it, I am going to keep looking. I have one last story to tell from my childhood. I was in a culture were being with boys and having sexual interactions with them is looked over. The only thing you are going to be killed for is that if you talk to someone else's female. I have never found contradictions in a culture as much as I found it in mine. There's this obsession with protecting women. From what you might ask, from being used or being put into the wrong relationship. Most of the religious rules hover around that as apposed to raising people's self esteem and educating them, you put fear into their hearts by any mean necessary, even if that meant concealing the truth or lying in many instances. I was abused three times in my life. It's still very hard for me to talk about it. I lied many times in my life to protect myself and religion never made me more honest. On the contrary, there were many mentions of favoring your brother believer and be cautious from the non-believers and never love them, otherwise, you are one of them. I am struggling now to find the reason why I can't believe in god with my heart and not look at what people impose upon me. It's very hard. Most people want to follow their religion to not bring shame or because there's an embedded guilt that if you don't believe, you are going to hell. Is that really sincere? sincere is when you believe because you want to believe, not because there's some entity higher than you forcing you to believe and threatening you to be damned to hell. Also, your interaction with people from other religions only tied to you trying to convert them.

The reason I am writing this book isn't to impose my views on you. I am only laying the ground to what I think the way we should treat people and look at them.

I think the reason I reject the idea completely is that I met many people and had the exposure that enabled me to have compassion and to see other people as human and not in anyways less than me. I was born a Muslim and even if I feel that I am blessed to be among the few in this world who chose to be from this right path. I can't bring myself to think that there are million others who are human beings that I feel compassionate toward. 

The first encounter I had was talking to my wife about Israel and Palestine and how it was one of the first things that made me think how narrow I used to look at the world. I told her: "I feel connected to Palestinians who fall victim to the prejudice of Israeli army!" she replied to me: "what about people who fall victim on the other side?" it completely shocked me and shook my core. I had no clue how one sided I used to think.

I am only a product of my culture, not my belief.

I want to be fair to everyone and put myself in their shoes and not judge them. It's very hard.

I am dedicated to helping others learn and be independent. I believe that education is the key unlocking people's potential. I sound like a politician.

I attended many lectures about Palestine and Israel. The people who came to talk about it still had the same views. The view that being nice is only a way for a person to preach religion. God, I really don't like that anymore.

I can't change the world. The only thing I can do is try to focus on myself and my career and help others help themselves.

Why do I feel happy when I am not thinking about my faith? what's this sense of relief that I feel?

Why do I feel more honest and upfront with people now?

Why do I care about people more and judge them less?

Why why why

I can't comprehendthe fact that one religion should rule all. I just can't. It's very narrow and very exclusive. I don't know who spreads this. I think it's evil. If there's anything more evil, it's the idea that you should protect yourself from others just to protect your faith. It's ugly and narrow.

I am out of thoughts ...

note.text: Why do I feel this way? Why do I harbor so much resenetment towards israelis. I know the answer. It's the way I grew up, it's the way as I was raised. It's the one side of inequality that I saw (the other being the israeli side that I didn't see). I cringe everytime I see a video about tel-aviv or any other city. I want to understand their side. My wife is jewish and I still consider her outside of that realm. It torments me to see people suffering. I hope that someday I will reach the understanding and acceptance that I have of other people as I do for israelis.

Is there an elite group that claims science as their own right and craft? is the scientific community too closed off to outsiders or are they its gate keepers? why can't a plumber discuss their findings in any physical phenomenon that they see? why is it that a scientist and a lab the only method of reaching a conclusion. Is it because we can control certain variables in a lab setting? well, what if we expand it beyond that? Can't we just leave science to the people, that way we can make others buy into it as much as we do.

The theory of everything, the only way we can understand the universe and unlock its mystery. That was the last thing mason unlocked. Mason is a farmer in a remote land. He finished his schooling in the city nearby, let's call it eutopolis. He developed a strict habit of unlocking the mysteries of the universe. He wasn't a scientist by any means, but for some reason, he had the dedication and persistence nobody would ever match. Armed with his 10 year old linux machine, he wrote two types of bots: a scanner and an analyzer. He would deploy these bots in the internet and they would retrieve any knowledge in the whole internet and try to predict where it's going next. He did it for 10 years. Trying to unlock the next invention while still under the radar. You see Mason was a crazy conspiracy theorist. He would never trust the scientific community to use his tools for good or governments for that matter. He had a plan to reach the theory of everything and use his findings to build a machine that would destroy all other machines. According to his estimates, human beings would destroy each other in the year 2022 or 2023.  

There is this myth that god is just a particle. A particle that if discovered would restart everything. A particle that is 10^-10 in diameter. I guess computers have cores that control everything and so is the universe. Nobody predicted god was so small!

7.title: it hurts me when I hear people say jews are the problem

note.text:
jews run the world, jews own holywood, jews pay politician, jews own banks, jews control everything. You see I married into a jewish family and every time I talk to my friends or family I hear the word "jew" in a negative way. Calling someone a jew is already considered an insult. We still have Nazi like mentality in this world. We picture jews as filthy and greedy. Let me tell you my impression being a Saudi and living in a country where I heard things about jews every day being the public enemy and the cause of all of our problems. We lost our promised land to Israelis. I watched news every day of Palestenians being slaughtered by soldiers, their home being destroyed. It was almost as if the jews were expelled from "our land", all of our problems would disappear. We are of course divided beyond belief and Politician and religious monarchs use jews to distract us from being free. Again as a Saudi living in Pittsburgh and living in a jewish neighborhood I really had my impression and my image of jews completely shattered. I only saw the most educated and talented people among jews. They are people that value education. They are intellectuals and they embody the idea of healthy skepticism.  They don't take things as they are, they always question things (which I was told in my culture was a bad thing). 

if you don't believe me, look at how many jews participated in the civil right movement. If anything jews were a huge part of equality than inequality in America.

Yes I am biased, I married a jewish woman and they tell you what to think (that's a joke).

to all my friends and family, please stop saying jew in a negative way, it really hurts me.

8.title: When are we going to judge society as individuals and not a group?

note.text: Have you every seen a family with drastically different siblings in terms of personality? that's it!

9.title: We are distracted! intentionally or not. We are distracted!

note.text:
As Bubby always said. it's a construct that we created that caused all of our misery. Status has been tied to identity for a long time. It's an unfair assessment of anyone's ability to perform in society. It's also not a basis for any behavioral pattern. I always resort to science for an answer. I try to disconnect myself from my identity, but unfortunately people define me by them. I am an Arab. I have been told that Arabs are lazy, racist, violant, impatient, backwards, anti-woman. Now, if I accept those facts, I am going to behave in such manner. It's very hard. My wife is Jewish, so she is what ... rich, controls the government, owns a bank, own the media. Imagine if she accepted that that's part of her identity, how would that affect her?


now let me define myself in a different way. I spent ages 5-8 in Athens, Ohio. I grew up in a middle class family, my dad worked, my mom didn't. I was always curious as a kid, I loved science and logic. I have siblings with varying personalities and goals. I feel in love with programming later on in my life after studying in college. I consider myself to be a programmer. I experiment a lot. I go through phases where i obsess with one thing and then completely move on to something else.

So, How would I define myself? am I an Arab programmer who hops from one thing to the next very quickly? I am not sure.

1.title: Human beings commit evil without knowing it

2.title: Our consciousness is limited. We only have a short period of time to live

note.text: If there is an example of auto-immune disease that could apply to a society, that society would be the US-of-A. I am amazed to see the american society so fearful yet very respectful and holds their law enforcement officers to the level of heroes. It just reminded me of auto-immune disease. We rely on our immune system to fight outside threats. Although its happening on a microscopic level, we still experience the same thing in our society, our immune system seems to fight us sometimes. We have seen a good number of police brutality in the past two years. Targeted mainly towards blacks in America, but that circle is expanding to other people, including but not limited to: Latinos, Muslims, Arabs and any other immigrant. I came from Saudi Arabia originally, the country tagged with 9/11. I still experience hesitation from people to not shy away when I tell them I am from Saudi Arabia. I am trying really hard to integrate into the american society, but perhaps it's not the right time. I love this country so much. It was a second chance for me to get back on my feet when things didn't work out in my original home. I went through a tough period living in Saudi Arabia. It wasn't all terrible, but I just didn't fit well with that culture, I am not going to go into details about my personal story, maybe for another time. Let me get back to my original point, our immune system. We really have to work hard to repair it!

note.text:
The study of human behavior and societies
[Anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropology) – study of humans, past and present, that draws and builds upon knowledge from the social sciences and biological sciences, as well as the humanities and the natural sciences.[Anthropology of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropology_of_religion) – study of religious institutions in relation to other social institutions, and the comparison of religious beliefs and practices across cultures

[Applied anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_anthropology) – application of the method and theory of anthropology to the analysis and solution of practical problems.

[Archaeology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_archaeology) – overview of and topical guide to archaeology

[Cultural anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_anthropology) – branch of anthropology focused on the study of cultural variation among humans, collecting data about the impact of global economic and political processes on local cultural realities.

[Ethnobiology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnobiology) – scientific study of dynamic relationships between peoples, biota, and environments, from the distant past to the immediate present.

[Ethnography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnography) – Archaeology Biological anthropology Cultural anthropology Linguistic anthropology Social anthropology

[Ethnology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnology) – branch of anthropology that compares and analyzes the origins, distribution, technology, religion, language, and social structure of the ethnic, racial, and/or national divisions of humanity.

[Ethnopoetics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnopoetics) – method of recording text versions of oral poetry or narrative performances (i.e., verbal lore) that uses poetic lines, verses, and stanzas (instead of prose paragraphs) to capture the formal, poetic performance elements which would otherwise be lost in the written texts.

[Evolutionary anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_anthropology) – interdisciplinary study of the evolution of human physiology and human behaviour and the relation between hominids and non-hominid primates.

[Experimental archaeology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_archaeology) – Experimental archaeology employs a number of different methods, techniques, analyses, and approaches in order to generate and test hypotheses, based upon archaeological source material, like ancient structures or artifacts.

[Historical archaeology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_archaeology) – form of archaeology dealing with topics that are already attested in written records.

[Linguistic anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_anthropology) – is the interdisciplinary study of how language influences social life.

[Medical anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_anthropology) – interdisciplinary field which studies "human health and disease, health care systems, and biocultural adaptation".

[Physical anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_anthropology) – study of the physical development of the human species.

[Psychological anthropology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_anthropology) – interdisciplinary subfield of anthropology that studies the interaction of cultural and mental processes.

[Zooarchaeology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zooarchaeology) – study of faunal remains.

[Anthrozoology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthrozoology) – study of human-animal interaction.

[Business studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_studies) – academic subject combining elements of accountancy, finance, marketing, organizational studies and economics

[Civics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civics) – study of the theoretical and practical aspects of citizenship, its rights and duties; the duties of citizens to each other as members of a political body and to the government.

[Cognitive Science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_Science) – interdisciplinary scientific study of the mind and its processes. It examines what cognition is, what it does and how it works.

[Criminology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criminology) – study of the nature, extent, causes, and control of criminal behavior in both the individual and in society.

[Cultural studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_studies) – academic field grounded in critical theory and literary criticism.

[Demography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demography) – statistical study of human populations and sub-populations.

[Development studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_studies) – multidisciplinary branch of social science which addresses issues of concern to developing countries.

[Economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_economics) – analyzes the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services. Not considered a science by some thinkers [4] It aims to explain how economies work and how economic agents interact.[Macroeconomics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroeconomics) – branch of economics dealing with the performance, structure, behavior, and decision-making of the whole economy

[Microeconomics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microeconomics) – branch of economics that studies the behavior of individual households and firms in making decisions on the allocation of limited resources

[Behavioural economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioural_economics) – Behavioral economics and the related field, behavioral finance, study the effects of social, cognitive and emotional factors on the economic decisions of individuals and institutions and the consequences for market prices, returns and the resource allocation.

[Bioeconomics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermoeconomics) – applies the laws of thermodynamics to economic theory

[Comparative economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_economics) – comparative study of different systems of economic organization, such as capitalism, socialism, feudalism and the mixed economy.[Socialist economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_economics) – economic theories and practices of hypothetical and existing socialist economic systems.

[Development economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_economics) – branch of economics which deals with economic aspects of the development process in low-income countries.

[Economic geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_geography) – study of the location, distribution and spatial organization of economic activities across the world.

[Economic history](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_history) – study of economies or economic phenomena in the past.

[Economic sociology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_sociology) – studies both the social effects and the social causes of various economic phenomena.

[Energy economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_economics) – broad scientific subject area which includes topics related to supply and use of energy in societies

[Entrepreneurial Economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entrepreneurial_Economics) – study of the entrepreneur and entrepreneurship within the economy.

[Environmental economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_economics) – subfield of economics concerned with environmental issues.

[Evolutionary economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics) – part of mainstream economics as well as heterodox school of economic thought that is inspired by evolutionary biology.

[Financial economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_economics) – branch of economics concerned with "the allocation and deployment of economic resources, both spatially and across time, in an uncertain environment".

[Heterodox economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterodox_economics) – approaches or to schools of economic thought that are considered outside of "mainstream economics" and sometimes contrasted by expositors with neoclassical economics.[Green economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_economics) – one that results in improved human well-being and social equity, while significantly reducing environmental risks

[Feminist economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist_economics) – diverse area of economic inquiry that highlights the androcentric biases of traditional economics through critical examinations of economic methodology, epistemology, history and empirical study.

[Islamic economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_economics) – body of Islamic studies literature that "identifies and promotes an economic order that conforms to Islamic scripture and traditions," and in the economic world an interest-free Islamic banking system, grounded in Sharia's condemnation of interest (riba).

[Industrial organization](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_organization) – field of economics that builds on the theory of the firm in examining the structure of, and boundaries between, firms and markets.

[International economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_economics) – study of the effects upon economic activity of international differences in productive resources and consumer preferences and the institutions that affect them.

[Institutional economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_economics) – study of the role of the evolutionary process and the role of institutions in shaping economic behaviour.

[Labor economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_economics) – seeks to understand the functioning and dynamics of the markets for labour.

[Law and Economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_and_Economics) – application of economic methods to analysis of law.

[Managerial economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Managerial_economics) – "application of economic concepts and economic analysis to the problems of formulating rational managerial decisions"

[Monetary economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monetary_economics) – branch of economics that historically prefigured and remains integrally linked to macroeconomics.

[Neuroeconomics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroeconomics) – interdisciplinary field that seeks to explain human decision making, the ability to process multiple alternatives and to choose an optimal course of action.

[Public finance](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_finance) – study of the role of the government in the economy.

[Public economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_economics) – study of government policy through the lens of economic efficiency and equity.

[Real estate economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_estate_economics) – application of economic techniques to real estate markets.

[Resource economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resource_economics) – study of supply, demand, and allocation of the Earth's natural resources.

[Welfare economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_economics) – branch of economics that uses microeconomic techniques to evaluate economic well-being, especially relative to competitive general equilibrium within an economy as to economic efficiency and the resulting income distribution associated with it.

[Political economy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_economy) – study of the production, buying, and selling, and their relations with law, custom, and government, as well as with the distribution of national income and wealth, including through the budget process.

[Socioeconomics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomics) – considers behavioral interactions of individuals and groups through social capital and social "markets" (not excluding for example, sorting by marriage) and the formation of social norms.

[Transport economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_economics) – branch of economics that deals with the allocation of resources within the transport sector and has strong linkages with civil engineering.

[Economic methodology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_methodology) – study of methods, especially the scientific method, in relation to economics, including principles underlying economic reasoning.[Computational economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_economics) – research discipline at the interface between computer science and economic and management science.

[Econometrics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Econometrics) – application of mathematics and statistical methods to economic data[Mathematical economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_economics) – application of mathematical methods to represent economic theories and analyze problems posed in economics.

[Economic statistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_statistics) – topic in applied statistics that concerns the collection, processing, compilation, dissemination, and analysis of economic data.[Time series](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_series) – sequence of data points, measured typically at successive time instants spaced at uniform time intervals.

[Experimental economics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_economics) – application of experimental methods to study economic questions.

[Environmental studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_environmental_studies) – interdisciplinary academic field which systematically studies human interaction with the environment.

[Gender and sexuality studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_studies) – field of interdisciplinary study and academic field devoted to gender identity and gendered representation as central categories of analysis.

[Geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_geography) – study of the lands, features, inhabitants, and phenomena of Earth.[Cartography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_cartography) – study and practice of making maps or globes.

[Human geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_geography) – branch of the social sciences that studies the world, its people, communities, and cultures with an emphasis on relations of and across space and place.[Critical geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_geography) – takes a critical theory (Frankfurt School) approach to the study and analysis of geography.

[Cultural geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_geography) – study of cultural products and norms and their variations across and relations to spaces and places.

[Feminist geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feminist_geography) – approach in human geography which applies the theories, methods and critiques of feminism to the study of the human environment, society and geographical space.

[Economic geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_geography) – study of the location, distribution and spatial organization of economic activities across the world.

[Development geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_geography) – branch of geography with reference to the standard of living and quality of life of its human inhabitants.

[Historical geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_geography) – study of the human, physical, fictional, theoretical, and "real" geographies of the past.

[Time geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_geography) –

[Political geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_geography) & [geopolitics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geopolitics) – field of human geography that is concerned with the study of both the spatially uneven outcomes of political processes and the ways in which political processes are themselves affected by spatial structures.

[Marxist geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxist_geography) – strand of critical geography that uses the theories and philosophy of Marxism to examine the spatial relations of human geography.

[Military geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_geography) – sub-field of geography that is used by, not only the military, but also academics and politicians to understand the geopolitical sphere through the militaristic lens.

[Strategic geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strategic_geography) – concerned with the control of, or access to, spatial areas that have an impact on the security and prosperity of nations.

[Population geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_geography) – study of the ways in which spatial variations in the distribution, composition, migration, and growth of populations are related to the nature of places.

[Social geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_geography) – branch of human geography that is most closely related to social theory in general and sociology in particular, dealing with the relation of social phenomena and its spatial components.

[Behavioral geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_geography) – approach to human geography that examines human behavior using a disaggregate approach.

[Children's geographies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Children%27s_geographies) – area of study within human geography and Childhood Studies which involves researching the places and spaces of children's lives.

[Health geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_geography) – application of geographical information, perspectives, and methods to the study of health, disease, and health care.

[Tourism geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tourism_geography) – study of travel and tourism, as an industry and as a social and cultural activity.

[Urban geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_geography) – study of areas which have a high concentration of buildings and infrastructure.

[Environmental geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_geography) – branch of geography that describes the spatial aspects of interactions between humans and the natural world.

[Physical geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_geography) – branch of natural science which deals with the study of processes and patterns in the natural environment like the atmosphere, biosphere and geosphere, as opposed to the cultural or built environment, the domain of human geography.[Biogeography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biogeography) – study of the distribution of species (biology), organisms, and ecosystems in geographic space and through geological time.

[Climatology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climatology) – Atmospheric physics Atmospheric dynamics (category)

[Palaeoclimatology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palaeoclimatology) – study of changes in climate taken on the scale of the entire history of Earth.

[Coastal geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coastal_geography) – study of the dynamic interface between the ocean and the land, incorporating both the physical geography (i.e. coastal geomorphology, geology and oceanography) and the human geography (sociology and history) of the coast.

[Geomorphology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geomorphology) – scientific study of landforms and the processes that shape them.

[Geodesy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodesy) – scientific discipline that deals with the measurement and representation of the Earth, including its gravitational field, in a three-dimensional time-varying space.

[Hydrology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_hydrology) – study of the movement, distribution, and quality of water on Earth and other planets, including the hydrologic cycle, water resources and environmental watershed sustainability.

[Hydrography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrography) – mapping (charting) of water topographic features through the measurement of the depths, the tides and currents of a body of water and establishment of the sea, river or lake bed topography and morphology.

[Glaciology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glaciology) – study of glaciers, or more generally ice and natural phenomena that involve ice.

[Limnology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limnology) – study of inland waters.

[Oceanography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceanography) – branch of Earth science that studies the ocean.

[Pedology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedology_(soil_study)) – study of soils in their natural environment.

[Landscape ecology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landscape_ecology) – science of studying and improving relationships between ecological processes in the environment and particular ecosystems.

[Palaeogeography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palaeogeography) – study of what the geography was in times past.

[Regional geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_geography) – study of world regions.

[Gerontology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerontology) – study of the social, psychological and biological aspects of aging.

[History](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_history) – discovery, collection, organization, and presentation of information about past events. History can also mean the period of time after writing was invented.

[Geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_geography) – science that studies the lands, features, inhabitants, and phenomena of Earth.[Human geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_geography) – branch of the social sciences that studies the world, its people, communities, and cultures with an emphasis on relations of and across space and place.

[Industrial relations](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_relations) – multidisciplinary field that studies the employment relationship.

[Information science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_science) – interdisciplinary field primarily concerned with the analysis, collection, classification, manipulation, storage, retrieval and dissemination of information.

[International studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_studies) – study of the major political, economic, social, cultural and sacral issues that dominate the international agenda

[Law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_law) – set of rules and principles (laws) by which a society is governed, through enforcement by governmental authorities.

[Legal management](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_management) – social sciences discipline that is designed for students interested in the study of State and its elements, Law, Law Practice, Legal Research and Jurisprudence, legal Philosophy, Criminal Justice, Governance, Government structure, Political history and theories, Business Organization and Management, Entrepreneurship, Public Administration and Human Resource Development.[Paralegal studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paralegal_studies) – social sciences discipline that is designed for students interested in the study of State and its elements, Law, Law Practice, Legal Research and Jurisprudence, legal Philosophy, Criminal Justice, Governance, Government structure, Political history and theories, Business Organization and Management, Entrepreneurship, Public Administration and Human Resource Development.

[Library science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_library_science) – study of issues related to libraries and the information fields.

[Linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_linguistics) – scientific study of natural language.[Anthropological linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropological_linguistics) – study of the relations between language and culture and the relations between human biology, cognition and language.

[Applied linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_linguistics) – interdisciplinary field of study that identifies, investigates, and offers solutions to language-related real-life problems.

[Biolinguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biolinguistics) – study of the biology and evolution of language.

[Clinical linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_linguistics) and [speech and language pathology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_and_language_pathology) – sub-discipline of linguistics which involves the application of linguistic theory to the field of Speech-Language Pathology.

[Cognitive linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_linguistics) – branch of linguistics that interprets language in terms of the concepts, sometimes universal, sometimes specific to a particular tongue, which underlie its forms.

[Comparative linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_linguistics) – branch of historical linguistics that is concerned with comparing languages to establish their historical relatedness.

[Computational linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_linguistics) – interdisciplinary field dealing with the statistical or rule-based modeling of natural language from a computational perspective.

[Developmental linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmental_linguistics) – study of the development of linguistic ability in an individual, particularly the acquisition of language in childhood.[language acquisition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_acquisition) – the process by which humans acquire the capacity to perceive and comprehend language, as well as to produce and use words to communicate.

[Dialectology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialectology) – scientific study of linguistic dialect, a sub-field of sociolinguistics.[dialectometry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialectometry) – the study of high levels of structure in geographical dialect networks.

[Discourse analysis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse_analysis) – general term for a number of approaches to analyzing written, spoken, signed language use or any significant semiotic event.

[Etymology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etymology) – study of the history of words, their origins, and how their form and meaning have changed over time.

[Evolutionary linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_linguistics) – the scientific study of both the origins and development of language as well as the cultural evolution of languages.

[Forensic linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forensic_linguistics) – application of linguistic knowledge, methods and insights to the forensic context of law, language, crime investigation, trial, and judicial procedure.

[Geolinguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geolinguistics) – branch of human geography that studies the geographic distribution of language or its constituent elements.

[Historical linguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_linguistics) – study of language change.

[Lexis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexis_(linguistics)) – total vocabulary or lexicon having items of lexical, rather than grammatical, meaning.

[Linguistic typology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_typology) – subfield of linguistics that studies and classifies languages according to their structural features.

[Morphology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(linguistics)) – identification, analysis and description of the structure of a given language's morphemes and other linguistic units, such as words, affixes, parts of speech, intonation/stress, or implied context (words in a lexicon are the subject matter of lexicology).

[Neurolinguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurolinguistics) – study of the neural mechanisms in the human brain that control the comprehension, production, and acquisition of language.

[Philology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philology) – study of language in written historical sources; it is a combination of literary studies, history and linguistics.

[Phonetics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonetics) – branch of linguistics that comprises the study of the sounds of human speech, orthe equivalent aspects of sign.

[Phonology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology) – branch of linguistics concerned with the systematic organization of sounds in languages.

[Phraseology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phraseology) – study of set or fixed expressions, such as idioms, phrasal verbs, and other types of multi-word lexical units (often collectively referred to as phrasemes), in which the component parts of the expression take on a meaning more specific than or otherwise not predictable from the sum of their meanings when used independently.

[Pragmatics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatics) – subfield of linguistics which studies the ways in which context contributes to meaning.

[Psycholinguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psycholinguistics) – study of the psychological and neurobiological factors that enable humans to acquire, use, comprehend and produce language.

[Sociolinguistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociolinguistics) – descriptive study of the effect of any and all aspects of society, including cultural norms, expectations, and context, on the way language is used, and the effects of language use on society.

[Speech science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_science) – Speech science refers to the study of production, transmission and perception of speech. Speech science involves anatomy, in particular the anatomy of the oro-facial region and neuroanatomy, physiology, and acoustics.

[Stylistics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stylistics_(linguistics)) – study and interpretation of texts from a linguistic perspective.

[Syntax](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax) – "the study of the principles and processes by which sentences are constructed in particular languages."

[Semantics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics) – study of meaning.

[Writing systems](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writing) and [orthography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthography) – representation of language in a textual medium through the use of a set of signs or symbols (known as a writing system).

[Management](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_business_management) – act of getting people together to accomplish desired goals and objectives using available resources efficiently and effectively.

[Media studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_studies) – academic discipline and field of study that deals with the content, history and effects of various media; in particular, the 'mass media'.[Communication studies](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_studies) – academic field that deals with processes of human communication, commonly defined as the sharing of symbols to create meaning.

[Philosophy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_philosophy) – study of general and fundamental problems concerning matters such as existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. Academic philosophy is considered a science by some.[5] Others say that philosophy is not a science but it is instead a precursor of it.[6] The role of philosophy is also a philosophical question.[7][Philosophy of language](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_language) – is concerned with four central problems: the nature of meaning, language use, language cognition, and the relationship between language and reality.

[Philosophy of information](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_information) – (PI) is the area of research that studies conceptual issues arising at the intersection of computer science, information science, information technology, and philosophy.

[Political philosophy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_philosophy) – is the study of topics such as politics, liberty, justice, property, rights, law, and the enforcement of a legal code by authority.

[Epistemology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_epistemology) – study of how we know what we know; study of the nature and scope of knowledge.

[Ethics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_ethics) – major branch of philosophy, encompassing right conduct and good life. It is significantly broader than the common conception of analyzing right and wrong.

[Logic](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_logic) – formal science of using reason

[Philosophy of mind](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_mind) – branch of philosophy that studies the nature of the mind, mental events, mental functions, mental properties, consciousness and their relationship to the physical body, particularly the brain.

[Philosophy of science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_science) – questions the assumptions, foundations, methods and implications of science; questions the use and merit of science; sometimes overlaps [metaphysics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaphysics) and epistemology by questioning whether scientific results are actually a study of truth.

[Social philosophy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_philosophy) – is the study of questions about social behavior and interpretations of society and social institutions in terms of ethical values rather than empirical relations.

[Aesthetics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesthetics) – is a branch of philosophy dealing with the nature of art, beauty, and taste, with the creation and appreciation of beauty.

[Philosophy of mathematics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_mathematics) – is the branch of philosophy that studies the philosophical assumptions, foundations, and implications of mathematics. The aim of the philosophy of mathematics is to provide an account of the nature and methodology of mathematics and to understand the place of mathematics in people's lives.

[Philosophy of education](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_education) – Philosophy of education can refer to either the academic field of applied philosophy or to one of any educational philosophies that promote a specific type or vision of education, and/or which examine the definition, goals and meaning of education.

[Political science](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_political_science) – social science discipline concerned with the study of the state, government, and politics.[Comparative politics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_politics) – field and a method used in political science, characterized by an empirical approach based on the comparative method.

[Game theory](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory) – study of strategic decision making.

[Geopolitics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geopolitics) – theory that describes the relation between politics and territory whether on local or international scale.[political geography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_geography) – field of human geography that is concerned with the study of both the spatially uneven outcomes of political processes and the ways in which political processes are themselves affected by spatial structures.

Ideology – set of ideas that constitute one's goals, expectations, and actions.

[Political economy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_economy) – Political economy originally was the term for studying production, buying, and selling, and their relations with law, custom, and government, as well as with the distribution of national income and wealth, including through the budget process. Political economy originated in moral philosophy. It developed in the 18th century as the study of the economies of states, polities, hence political economy.

[Political psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_psychology), bureaucratic, administrative and judicial behaviour –

[Psephology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psephology) – branch of political science which deals with the study and scientific analysis of elections.

[Voting systems](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voting_systems) – methods by which voters make a choice between options, often in an election or on a policy referendum.

[Public administration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_administration) – houses the implementation of government policy and an academic discipline that studies this implementation and that prepares civil servants for this work.[Public policy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_policy) – generally the principled guide to action taken by the administrative or executive branches of the state with regard to a class of issues in a manner consistent with law and institutional customs.

Local government studies – form of public administration which in a majority of contexts, exists as the lowest tier of administration within the a given state.

[International politics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_politics) – study of relationships between countries, including the roles of states, inter-governmental organizations (IGOs), international nongovernmental organizations (INGOs), non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and multinational corporations (MNCs).

[International relations theory](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_relations_theory) – study of international relations from a theoretical perspective; it attempts to provide a conceptual framework upon which international relations can be analyzed.

[Psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_psychology) – science of behavior and mental processes[Applied psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_psychology) – use of psychological principles and theories to overcome problems in other areas, such as mental health, business management, education, health, product design, ergonomics, and law.[Psychological testing](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_testing) – field characterized by the use of samples of behavior in order to assess psychological construct(s), such as cognitive and emotional functioning, about a given individual.

[Clinical psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_psychology) – integration of science, theory and clinical knowledge for the purpose of understanding, preventing, and relieving psychologically based distress or dysfunction and to promote subjective well-being and personal development.

[Community psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_psychology) – Sense of community Social capital

[Consumer behaviour](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_behaviour) – study of when, why, how, and where people do or do not buy a product.

[Counseling psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counseling_psychology) – psychological specialty that encompasses research and applied work in several broad domains: counseling process and outcome; supervision and training; career development and counseling; and prevention and health.

[Educational psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational_psychology) – study of how humans learn in educational settings, the effectiveness of educational interventions, the psychology of teaching, and the social psychology of schools as organizations.

[Forensic psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forensic_psychology) – intersection between psychology and the courtroom—criminal, civil, family and Federal.

[Health psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_psychology) – concerned with understanding how biological, psychological, environmental, and cultural factors are involved in physical health and illness.

[Industrial and organizational psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_and_organizational_psychology) – scientific study of employees, workplaces, and organizations.

[Legal psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legal_psychology) – involves empirical, psychological research of the law, legal institutions, and people who come into contact with the law.

[Media psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_psychology) – seeks an understanding of how people perceive, interpret, use, and respond to a media-rich world.

[Military psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_psychology) – research, design and application of psychological theories and experimentation data towards understanding, predicting and countering behaviours either in friendly or enemy forces or civilian population that may be undesirable, threatening or potentially dangerous to the conduct of military operations.

[Occupational health psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupational_health_psychology) – concerned with the psychosocial characteristics of workplaces that contribute to the development of health-related problems in people who work.

[Pastoral psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_Religion#Pastoral_psychology) – application of psychological methods and interpretive frameworks to religious traditions, as well as to both religious and irreligious individuals.

[Political psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_psychology) – interdisciplinary academic field dedicated to understanding political science, politicians and political behavior through the use of psychological theories.

[Psychometrics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics) – field of study concerned with the theory and technique of psychological measurement, which includes the measurement of knowledge, abilities, attitudes, personality traits, and educational measurement.

[School psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_psychology) – field that applies principles of clinical psychology and educational psychology to the diagnosis and treatment of children's and adolescents' behavioral and learning problems.

[Sport psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sport_psychology) – interdisciplinary science that draws on knowledge from the fields of Kinesiology and Psychology.

[Systems psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_psychology) – branch of applied psychology that studies human behaviour and experience in complex systems.

[Traffic psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_psychology) – study of the behavior of road users and the psychological processes underlying that behavior (Rothengatter, 1997, 223) as well as to the relationship between behavior and accidents

[Behavior analysis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_analysis) – philosophy of psychology based on the proposition that all things that organisms do can and should be regarded as behaviors, and that psychological disorders are best treated by altering behavior patterns or modifying the environment.

[Biopsychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopsychology) – application of the principles of biology (in particular neurobiology), to the study of physiological, genetic, and developmental mechanisms of behavior in human and non-human animals.

[Cognitive psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology) – subdiscipline of psychology exploring internal mental processes.

[Clinical psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clinical_psychology) – integration of science, theory and clinical knowledge for the purpose of understanding, preventing, and relieving psychologically based distress or dysfunction and to promote subjective well-being and personal development.

[Cultural psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_psychology) – field of psychology which assumes the idea that culture and mind are inseparable, and that psychological theories grounded in one culture are likely to be limited in applicability when applied to a different culture.

[Developmental psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmental_psychology) – scientific study of systematic psychological changes, emotional changes, and perception changes that occur in human beings over the course of their life span.

[Educational psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Educational_psychology) – study of how humans learn in educational settings, the effectiveness of educational interventions, the psychology of teaching, and the social psychology of schools as organizations.

[Evolutionary psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology) – approach in the social and natural sciences that examines psychological traits such as memory, perception, and language from a modern evolutionary perspective.

[Experimental psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_psychology) – application of experimental methods to the study of behavior and the processes that underlie it.

[Forensic psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forensic_psychology) – intersection between psychology and the courtroom—criminal, civil, family and Federal.

[Health psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_psychology) – concerned with understanding how biological, psychological, environmental, and cultural factors are involved in physical health and illness.

[Humanistic psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_psychology) – psychological perspective which rose to prominence in the mid-20th century in the context of the tertiary sector beginning to produce in the most developed countries in the world more than the secondary sector was producing, for the first time in human history demanding creativity and new understanding of human capital.

[Industrial and organizational psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_and_organizational_psychology) – scientific study of employees, workplaces, and organizations.

[Music therapy](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_therapy) – allied health profession and one of the expressive therapies, consisting of an interpersonal process in which a trained music therapist uses music to help clients to improve or maintain their health.

[Neuropsychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuropsychology) – studies the structure and function of the brain as they relate to specific psychological processes and behaviors.

[Personality psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_psychology) – branch of psychology that studies personality and individual differences.

[Psychometrics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics) – field of study concerned with the theory and technique of psychological measurement, which includes the measurement of knowledge, abilities, attitudes, personality traits, and educational measurement.

[Psychology of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_religion) – application of psychological methods and interpretive frameworks to religious traditions, as well as to both religious and irreligious individuals.

[Psychophysics](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychophysics) – quantitatively investigates the relationship between physical stimuli and the sensations and perceptions they affect.

[Sensation and perception psychology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensation_and_perception_psychology) –

[Public administration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_administration) – houses the implementation of government policy and an academic discipline that studies this implementation and that prepares civil servants for this work.

[Social work](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_work) – professional and academic discipline that seeks to improve the quality of life and wellbeing of an individual, group, or community by intervening through research, policy, community organizing, direct practice, and teaching on behalf of those afflicted with poverty or any real or perceived social injustices and violations of their human rights.

[Sociology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_sociology) – studies society using various methods of empirical investigation and critical analysis to understand human social activity, from the micro level of individual agency and interaction to the macro level of systems and social structure.[Criminology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criminology) – study of the nature, extent, causes, and control of criminal behavior in both the individual and in society.

[Demography](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demography) – statistical study of human populations and sub-populations.
